summary.seg: This Greek manuscript, containing a part of the second-century author Theon of Smyrna's Treatise on aspects of mathematics useful for the reading of Plato, is an elegant copy written by the scribe Iakobos Diassorinos, who was librarian of the royal library at Fontainebleau around the middle of the 16th century. The codex is written in a large calligraphic script with lots of space on the page. The headpiece which opens the book depicts a shield bearing the three lilies of France and the three lions of England.

msItem.author: Theon, of Smyrna
msItem.title: De utilitate mathematicae
Aspects of Mathematics Useful for the Reading of Plato
msItem.note: The treatise is incomplete (ed. E. Hiller, Theonis Smyrnaei philosophi Platonici expositio rerum mathematicarum ad legendum Platonem utilium, Leipzig 1878, pp. 1-119), and, as in other exemplars of the tradition of Theon of Smyrna's text, it is divided in two, the part corresponding to Hiller 1878, pp. 46 l. 20-119 being considered as a separate text, on music (see Hiller 1878, p. VII)

msItem.author: Theon, of Smyrna
msItem.title: De utilitate mathematicae, excerptum
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Θέωνος Σμυρναίου πλατωνικοῦ τῶν κατὰ μαθηματικὸν χρησίμων εἰς τὴν τοῦ Πλάτωνος ἀνάγνωσιν
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Ὅτι μὲν οὐχ οἷον τε συνεῖναι τῶν μαθηματικῶς λεγομένων παρὰ Πλάτωνι
msItem.explicit: f. [36]v ἐν γὰρ τρισὶ διαστάσεσι τὸ στερεὸν νοεῖται.
msItem.note: As in other exemplars of the tradition, Theon of Smyrna's text is divided in two parts; this is Hiller 1878, pp. 1-46 l. 19

msItem.author: Theon, of Smyrna
msItem.title: De utilitate mathematicae, excerptum (De musica)
msItem.note: Part of the title has been written by the scribe on the upper edge of the leaf, as an instruction for the rubricator
msItem.incipit: f. [37]r Ἐπεὶ δὲ καὶ συμφώνους τινὰς φασὶν ἀριθμούς
msItem.explicit: f. 94r λείπεται δὲ μνημονεῦσαι στοιχειωδῶς καὶ τῶν κατ’ ἀστρονομίαν.
msItem.note: As in other exemplars of the tradition, Theon of Smyrna's text is divided in two parts; this is Hiller 1878, pp. 46 l. 20-119

support.material: Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermarks: ff. 9-46 no watermarks are visible. ff. 1-8 Anchor in a circle surmounted by a five-point-star; under the circle number 3, countermark CAC (not very clearly visible), in the corner ( 95 40 ) in the gutter, without exact correspondence in the main repertoires. ff. [i]-[iii], 47-[v] Monogram in a shield with letters W and X surmounted by a four-leaf-clover, under the shield name (particulars are difficult to see) ( ca. 40 35 ) in the gutter comparable to Briquet, Lettres et monogrammes 9869-9870, which are dated to 1534 and 1536, with variants dated until 1549.

supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, in Arabic numerals, only on the first leaf, recto, of each quire, in the top right-hand corner, from 1 ( f. 1r) to 94 ( f. 94r): [i]-[iii] + 1-94 + [iv]-[v].

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 1 binion (formed by 3 leaves, the first being probably the left pastedown), 5 quaternions, 1 ternion, 6 quaternions and 1 binion which lacks the third leaf, the last is probably the right pastedown.
collation.catchwords: Vertical catchwords in the scribe's hand on the last verso, lower part, near the gutter; very short, they are written from the top down.

supportDesc.condition: The manuscript is in good condition. There is a tear in the margin of f. [69]r The cover of the binding is damaged on the spine.

handNote.p:
ff. 1r-94r Hand A: the text has been written entirely by
Iakobos Diassorinos (16th c., 2nd quarter-1563) Diassorinus, Jacobus (16th c., 2nd quarter- 1563) , (Ἰάκωβος Διασσωρινός, RGK I, 143. See also RGK II, 191; RGK III, 241), in the more calligraphic variant of his script.
The text is written in black ink; titles and initials in red and in gold.
The principal titles of the works are written in majuscule letters.
The scribe wrote a few additions in the margins in black and red ink.
Passim some loops have been coloured in gold.

decoDesc.decoNote: On f. 1r there is a rectangular headpiece coloured in blue, with a golden frame. In the centre there is a shield divided in four; two divisions contain three lilies of France, and two three lions of England. The shield is surrounded by a laurel wreath, which is surmounted by a crown. Around the shield, there are pomegranates. The colours are blue, gold, red and green. The headpiece and the titles probably were not realised by the scribe: on ff. 1r and [37]r are still visible two annotations written by the scribe on the upper edge of the leaves, indicating the title which was to be written on each folio (title on f. [37]r remained incomplete).
On f. 1r there is a large golden initial in ekthesis, richly decorated with a vegetal motif with vine scrolls.
Thick golden initials in ekthesis throughout the text, see e.g. f. [20]v.
A golden flower accompanies the title of a paragraph on f. [12]r.
Some diagrams accompany the text in black ink, red and gold, see e.g. ff. 55v, [74]r.

additions.p: On f. [iii] verso there is a Latin title for the work: Theonis Smyrnaei platonici de iis, quae sunt utilia mathematico ad lectionem Platonis.
On f. 94v there is a Greek annotation, by another hand, Λόγων ἐνθάδε ποταμὸς νοῦ δὲ σταλάγμος.
A later hand wrote on f. [i] recto a note concerning the quality of the script, Haec est pulcra manus, sed qui sic iudicet errat, nam fuerant istaec carmina scripta pede.
On the left pastedown is written the shelfmark of the manuscript, which is also written (only the number 23) in the upper margin, right, of f. 1r.

binding.p: Modern western binding. Full red velvet cover on green background over wooden boards. Painted gauffered edges in blue and red. In the lower part of the spine, paper label with shelfmark.
binding.condition: There is a hole through the left board towards the foredge, just above the centre. The textile on spine is worn out.

history.origin: The manuscript was copied by Iakobos Diassorinos between the second quarter and the sixth decade of the 16th century.
history.acquisition: The manuscript was certainly present in King's College Library by 1600, given that it is listed as number 5 among the manuscripts of the library in T. James, Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis, Londini 1600, p. 138. On the left pastedown is glued the King's College bookplate.

recordHist.source: Description (2020) partly draws on M.R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the Manuscripts other than Oriental in the Library of King's College, Cambridge, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1895, p. 41.

availability.p: Visitors to King's College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: King's College Library.

item.term: Theon, of Smyrna. Expositio rerum mathematicarum ad legendum Platonem utilium
